data.Aberrant: Departing from an accepted standard or norm; deviating from what is considered normal or typical.
data.Abhorrent: Causing or deserving strong dislike, disgust, or hatred.
data.Abrasive: Harsh or rough in manner; tending to rub or wear away by friction.
data.Abscond: To leave hurriedly and secretly, typically to avoid detection or arrest.
data.Acquiesce: To accept something reluctantly but without protest.
data.Adamant: Refusing to be persuaded or to change one's mind.
data.Admonish: To warn or reprimand someone firmly.
data.Aloof: Not friendly or forthcoming; cool and distant.
data.Amiable: Having or displaying a friendly and pleasant manner.
data.Anomaly: Something that deviates from what is standard, normal, or expected.
data.Aplomb: Self-confidence or assurance, especially when in a demanding situation.
data.Arbitrary: Based on random choice or personal whim, rather than any reason or system.
data.Audacious: Showing a willingness to take surprisingly bold risks; showing an impudent lack of respect.
data.Banter: The playful and friendly exchange of teasing remarks.
data.Brevity: Concise and exact use of words in writing or speech.
data.Cacophony: A harsh, discordant mixture of sounds.
data.Capricious: Given to sudden and unaccountable changes of mood or behavior.
data.Cathartic: Providing psychological relief through the open expression of strong emotions.
data.Clandestine: Kept secret or done secretively, especially because illicit.
data.Coalesce: To come together and form one mass or whole.
data.Concise: Giving a lot of information clearly and in a few words; brief but comprehensive.
data.Confluence: The junction of two rivers, especially rivers of approximately equal width.
data.Conundrum: A confusing and difficult problem or question.
data.Corpulent: Fat; having a large, bulky body.
data.Curtail: To reduce in extent or quantity; impose a restriction on.
data.Debacle: A sudden and ignominious failure; a fiasco.
data.Debilitate: To make someone weak and infirm.
data.Debunk: To expose the falseness or hollowness of (a myth, idea, or belief).
data.Decipher: To convert (a text written in code, or a coded signal) into normal language.
data.Derivative: Imitative of the work of another person, and usually disapproved of for that reason.
data.Desolate: Deserted of people and in a state of bleak and dismal emptiness.
data.Dilapidated: In a state of disrepair or ruin as a result of age or neglect.
data.Disparage: To regard or represent as being of little worth.
data.Eclectic: Deriving ideas, style, or taste from a broad and diverse range of sources.
data.Efficacious: Successful in producing a desired or intended result; effective.
data.Emulate: To match or surpass (a person or achievement), typically by imitation.
data.Enigma: A person or thing that is mysterious, puzzling, or difficult to understand.
data.Enigmatic: Difficult to interpret or understand; mysterious.
data.Enumerate: To mention (a number of things) one by one.
data.Ephemeral: Lasting for a very short time.
data.Epiphany: A moment of sudden revelation or insight.
data.Equanimity: Mental calmness, composure, and evenness of temper, especially in a difficult situation.
data.Erudite: Having or showing great knowledge or learning.
data.Esoteric: Intended for or likely to be understood by only a small number of people with a specialized knowledge or interest.
data.Ethereal: Extremely delicate and light in a way that seems too perfect for this world.
data.Exacerbate: To make (a problem, bad situation, or negative feeling) worse.
data.Exemplary: Serving as a desirable model; representing the best of its kind.
data.Exonerate: To absolve (someone) from blame for a fault or wrongdoing, especially after due consideration of the case.
data.Exorbitant: Exceeding the bounds of custom, propriety, or reason, especially in amount or extent.
data.Exuberant: Filled with or characterized by a lively energy and excitement.
data.Facetious: Treating serious issues with deliberately inappropriate humor; flippant.
data.Fervent: Having or displaying a passionate intensity.
data.Furtive: Attempting to avoid notice or attention, typically because of guilt or a belief that discovery would lead to trouble.
data.Garrulous: Excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters.
data.Harbinger: A person or thing that announces or signals the approach of another.
data.Impetuous: Acting or done quickly and without thought or care.
data.Indelible: Making marks that cannot be removed.
data.Ineffable: Too great or extreme to be expressed or described in words.
data.Insidious: Proceeding in a gradual, subtle way, but with harmful effects.
data.Intrepid: Fearless; adventurous (often used for rhetorical or humorous effect).
data.Inveterate: Having a particular habit, activity, or interest that is long-established and unlikely to change.
data.Irascible: Having or showing a tendency to be easily angered.
data.Juxtapose: To place or deal with close together for contrasting effect.
data.Labyrinthine: Complicated and confusing, like a labyrinth.
data.Languid: Displaying or having a disinclination for physical exertion or effort; slow and relaxed.
data.Lethargic: Affected by lethargy; sluggish and apathetic.
data.Magnanimous: Very generous or forgiving, especially toward a rival or someone less powerful than oneself.
data.Malevolent: Having or showing a wish to do evil to others.
data.Maudlin: Self-pityingly or tearfully sentimental, often through drunkenness.
data.Melancholy: A feeling of pensive sadness, typically with no obvious cause.
data.Mercurial: Subject to sudden or unpredictable changes of mood or mind.
data.Meticulous: Showing great attention to detail; very careful and precise.
data.Mitigate: To make less severe, serious, or painful.
data.Nostalgic: Characterized by or exhibiting feelings of nostalgia.
data.Obfuscate: To render obscure, unclear, or unintelligible.
data.Obsequious: Obedient or attentive to an excessive or servile degree.
data.Ominous: Giving the impression that something bad or unpleasant is going to happen; threatening; inauspicious.
data.Opulent: Ostentatiously rich and luxurious or lavish.
data.Palpable: Able to be touched or felt.
data.Panacea: A solution or remedy for all difficulties or diseases.
data.Parsimonious: Unwilling to spend money or use resources; stingy or frugal.
data.Penchant: A strong or habitual liking for something or tendency to do something.
data.Perfunctory: Carried out with a minimum of effort or reflection.
data.Pernicious: Having a harmful effect, especially in a gradual or subtle way.
data.Plethora: A large or excessive amount of something.
data.Pragmatic: Dealing with things sensibly and realistically in a way that is based on practical rather than theoretical considerations.
data.Precarious: Not securely held or in position; dangerously likely to fall or collapse.
data.Precocious: Having developed certain abilities or proclivities at an earlier age than usual.
data.Predilection: A preference or special liking for something; a bias in favor of something.
data.Profane: Relating or devoted to that which is not sacred or biblical; secular rather than religious.
data.Prolific: Producing much fruit or foliage or many offspring.
data.Pugnacious: Eager or quick to argue, quarrel, or fight.
data.Quagmire: A soft boggy area of land that gives way underfoot; an awkward, complex, or hazardous situation.
data.Quell: To put an end to (a rebellion or other disorder), typically by the use of force.
data.Rancor: Bitterness or resentfulness, especially when long-standing.
data.Ravenous: Extremely hungry; devouring or craving food in great quantities.
data.Recalcitrant: Having an obstinately uncooperative attitude towards authority or discipline.
data.Recluse: A person who lives a solitary life and tends to avoid other people.
data.Relegate: To consign or dismiss to an inferior rank or position.
data.Remonstrate: To make a forcefully reproachful protest.
data.Reticent: Not revealing one's thoughts or feelings readily.
data.Sanguine: Optimistic or positive, especially in an apparently bad or difficult situation.
data.Scrupulous: Diligent, thorough, and extremely attentive to details.
data.Serendipity: The occurrence and development of events by chance in a happy or beneficial way.
data.Soporific: Tending to induce drowsiness or sleep.
data.Spurious: Not being what it purports to be; false or fake.
data.Stagnant: Having no current or flow and often having an unpleasant smell as a consequence.
data.Stoic: Enduring pain and hardship without showing one's feelings or complaining.
data.Sycophant: A person who acts obsequiously toward someone important in order to gain advantage.
data.Taciturn: Reserved or uncommunicative in speech; saying little.
data.Tantamount: Equivalent in seriousness to; virtually the same as.
data.Tawdry: Showy but cheap and of poor quality.
data.Trepidation: A feeling of fear or agitation about something that may happen.
data.Umbrage: Annoyance or resentment, typically at some perceived slight or insult.
data.Vacuous: Having or showing a lack of thought or intelligence; mindless.
data.Vapid: Offering nothing that is stimulating or challenging; bland.
data.Vehement: Showing strong feeling; forceful, passionate, or intense.
data.Venerate: To regard with great respect; revere.
data.Vicarious: Experienced in the imagination through the feelings or actions of another person.
data.Vindicate: To clear (someone) of blame or suspicion.
data.Virulent: Extremely severe or harmful in its effects.
data.Visceral: Relating to deep inward feelings rather than to the intellect.
data.Vociferous: Expressing or characterized by vehement opinions; loud and forceful.
data.Wary: Feeling or showing caution about possible dangers or problems.
data.Whimsical: Playfully quaint or fanciful, especially in an appealing and amusing way.
data.Winsome: Attractive or appealing in appearance or character.
data.Abrogate: To repeal or abolish by formal or official means.
data.Adroit: Clever or skillful in using the hands or mind.
data.Banal: So lacking in originality as to be obvious and boring.
data.Cadence: A modulation or inflection of the voice.
data.Callous: Showing or having an insensitive and cruel disregard for others.
data.Catharsis: The process of releasing, and thereby providing relief from, strong or repressed emotions.
data.Censure: Express severe disapproval of (someone or something), typically in a formal statement.
data.Cognizant: Having knowledge or being aware of.
data.Complacent: Showing smug or uncritical satisfaction with oneself or one's achievements.
data.Conciliatory: Intended or likely to placate or pacify.
data.Contrite: Feeling or expressing remorse or penitence; affected by guilt.
data.Cryptic: Having a meaning that is mysterious or obscure.
data.Despondent: In low spirits from loss of hope or courage.
data.Dichotomy: A division or contrast between two things that are or are represented as being opposed or entirely different.
data.Disingenuous: Not candid or sincere, typically by pretending that one knows less about something than one really does.
data.Dissident: A person who opposes official policy, especially that of an authoritarian state.
data.Docile: Ready to accept control or instruction; submissive.
data.Eloquent: Fluent or persuasive in speaking or writing.
data.Enervate: To cause (someone) to feel drained of energy or vitality; weaken.
data.Ennui: A feeling of listlessness and dissatisfaction arising from a lack of occupation or excitement.
data.Epitome: A person or thing that is a perfect example of a particular quality or type.
data.Equivocate: To use ambiguous language so as to conceal the truth or avoid committing oneself.
data.Expedite: To make (an action or process) happen sooner or be accomplished more quickly.
data.Expunge: To erase or remove completely (something unwanted or unpleasant).
data.Extraneous: Irrelevant or unrelated to the subject being dealt with.
data.Fervor: Intense and passionate feeling or enthusiasm.
data.Fortuitous: Happening by accident or chance rather than design.
data.Frivolous: Not having any serious purpose or value.
data.Histrionic: Overly theatrical or melodramatic in character or style.
data.Idiosyncrasy: A mode of behavior or way of thought peculiar to an individual.
data.Ignominious: Deserving or causing public disgrace or shame.
data.Impervious: Not allowing fluid to pass through; unable to be affected by.
data.Incandescent: Emitting light as a result of being heated.
data.Indignant: Feeling or showing anger or annoyance at what is perceived as unfair treatment.
data.Indolent: Wanting to avoid activity or exertion; lazy.
data.Inept: Having or showing no skill; clumsy.
data.Ingratiate: Bring oneself into favor with someone by flattering or trying to please them.
data.Innuendo: An allusive or oblique remark or hint, typically a suggestive or disparaging one.
data.Insolent: Showing a rude and arrogant lack of respect.
data.Invective: Insulting, abusive, or highly critical language.
data.Jaded: Tired, bored, or lacking enthusiasm, typically after having had too much of something.
data.Jaunty: Having or expressing a lively, cheerful, and self-confident manner.
data.Jocular: Characterized by joking; humorous or playful.
data.Jubilant: Feeling or expressing great happiness and triumph.
data.Juxtaposition: The fact of two things being seen or placed close together with contrasting effect.
data.Kinetic: Relating to or resulting from motion.
data.Kowtow: Act in an excessively subservient manner.
data.Lament: A passionate expression of grief or sorrow.
data.Languish: To lose or lack vitality; grow weak or feeble.
data.Largesse: Generosity in bestowing money or gifts upon others.
data.Lethargy: A lack of energy and enthusiasm.
data.Loathe: Feel intense dislike or disgust for.
data.Luminous: Full of or shedding light; bright or shining, especially in the dark.
data.Maelstrom: A powerful whirlpool in the sea or a river.
data.Magnate: A wealthy and influential businessman or businesswoman.
data.Malaise: A general feeling of discomfort, illness, or unease whose exact cause is difficult to identify.
data.Malice: The intention or desire to do evil; ill will.
data.Mellifluous: Sweet or musical; pleasant to hear.
data.Mirth: Amusement, especially as expressed in laughter.
data.Misanthrope: A person who dislikes humankind and avoids human society.
data.Misnomer: A wrong or inaccurate name or designation.
data.Modicum: A small quantity of a particular thing, especially something desirable or valuable.
data.Mollify: To appease the anger or anxiety of (someone).
data.Myriad: A countless or extremely great number.
data.Nadir: The lowest point in the fortunes of a person or organization.
data.Nuance: A subtle difference in or shade of meaning, expression, or sound.
data.Obdurate: Stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or course of action.
data.Oblique: Slanting or sloping; not explicit or done in a direct way.
data.Oblivion: The state of being unaware or unconscious of what is happening.
data.Onerous: Involving an amount of effort and difficulty that is oppressively burdensome.
data.Opaque: Not able to be seen through; not transparent.
data.Ornate: Made in an intricate shape or decorated with complex patterns.
data.Palliate: To make (a disease or its symptoms) less severe or unpleasant without removing the cause.
data.Paradox: A seemingly absurd or self-contradictory statement or proposition that when investigated or explained may prove to be well founded or true.
data.Paragon: A person or thing regarded as a perfect example of a particular quality.
data.Paucity: The presence of something in only small quantities or amounts; scarcity.
data.Piquant: Having a pleasantly sharp taste or appetizing flavor.
data.Ponderous: Slow and clumsy because of great weight.
data.Portent: A sign or warning that something, especially something momentous or calamitous, is likely to happen.
data.Pretentious: Attempting to impress by affecting greater importance, talent, culture, etc., than is actually possessed.
data.Prudent: Acting with or showing care and thought for the future.
data.Quandary: A state of perplexity or uncertainty over what to do in a difficult situation.
data.Quotidian: Of or occurring every day; daily.
data.Raze: Completely destroy (a building, town, or other site).
data.Rebuke: Express sharp disapproval or criticism of (someone) because of their behavior or actions.
data.Refute: Prove (a statement or theory) to be wrong or false; disprove.
data.Remiss: Lacking care or attention to duty; negligent.
data.Repudiate: Refuse to accept or be associated with.
data.Resilient: Able to withstand or recover quickly from difficult conditions.
data.Respite: A short period of rest or relief from something difficult or unpleasant.
data.Ruse: An action intended to deceive someone; a trick.
data.Sacrosanct: Regarded as too important or valuable to be interfered with.
data.Savvy: Shrewdness and practical knowledge, especially in politics or business.
data.Scurrilous: Making or spreading scandalous claims about someone with the intention of damaging their reputation.
data.Serpentine: Of or like a serpent or snake.
data.Sinister: Giving the impression that something harmful or evil is happening or will happen.
data.Solace: Comfort or consolation in a time of distress or sadness.
data.Solicitous: Characterized by or showing interest or concern.
data.Soliloquy: An act of speaking one's thoughts aloud when by oneself or regardless of any hearers, especially by a character in a play.
data.Somber: Dark or dull in color or tone; gloomy.
data.Squalid: Foul and repulsive, as from lack of care or cleanliness; neglected and filthy.
data.Staunch: Very loyal and committed in attitude.
data.Stipulate: To demand or specify (a requirement), typically as part of a bargain or agreement.
data.Sublime: Of such excellence, grandeur, or beauty as to inspire great admiration or awe.
data.Subterfuge: Deceit used in order to achieve one's goal.
data.Supercilious: Behaving or looking as though one thinks one is superior to others.
data.Supplicate: Ask or beg for something earnestly or humbly.
data.Surreptitious: Kept secret, especially because it would not be approved of.
data.Tactile: Of or connected with the sense of touch.
data.Tantalize: Torment or tease (someone) with the sight or promise of something that is unobtainable.
data.Taut: Stretched or pulled tight; not slack.
data.Tempestuous: Characterized by strong and turbulent or conflicting emotion.
data.Tenacious: Tending to keep a firm hold of something; clinging or adhering closely.
data.Terse: Sparing in the use of words; abrupt.
data.Timorous: Showing or suffering from nervousness, fear, or a lack of confidence.
data.Tirade: A long, angry speech of criticism or accusation.
data.Tome: A book, especially a large, heavy, scholarly one.
data.Travesty: A false, absurd, or distorted representation of something.
data.Truculent: Eager or quick to argue or fight; aggressively defiant.
data.Unassailable: Unable to be attacked, questioned, or defeated.
data.Unilateral: Performed by or affecting only one person, group, or country involved in a particular situation, without the agreement of another or the others.
data.Unscrupulous: Having or showing no moral principles; not honest or fair.
data.Untenable: Not able to be maintained or defended against attack or objection.
data.Unwitting: Not aware of the full facts; not done on purpose.
data.Upbraid: To find fault with or reproach severely; censure.
data.Urbane: Suave, courteous, and refined in manner.
data.Usurp: To take (a position of power or importance) illegally or by force.
data.Vacillate: To waver between different opinions or actions; be indecisive.
data.Verbose: Using or expressed in more words than are needed.
data.Vex: Make (someone) feel annoyed, frustrated, or worried, especially with trivial matters.
data.Vindictive: Having or showing a strong or unreasoning desire for revenge.
data.Voracious: Wanting or devouring great quantities of food.
data.Wane: To decrease in vigor, power, or extent; become weaker.
data.Wistful: Having or showing a feeling of vague or regretful longing.
data.Wrath: Extreme anger (chiefly used for humorous or rhetorical effect).
data.Abash: Cause to feel embarrassed, disconcerted, or ashamed.
data.Abate: Cause to become smaller or less intense.
data.Abridge: Shorten (a piece of writing) without losing the sense.
data.Absolve: Set or declare (someone) free from blame, guilt, or responsibility.
data.Acme: The point at which someone or something is best, perfect, or most successful.
data.Adept: Very skilled or proficient at something.
data.Affable: Friendly, good-natured, or easy to talk to.
data.Amicable: Having a spirit of friendliness; without serious disagreement or rancor.
data.Antithesis: A person or thing that is the direct opposite of someone or something else.
data.Ascertain: Find (something) out for certain; make sure of.
data.Banish: Send (someone) away from a country or place as an official punishment.
data.Cajole: Persuade (someone) to do something by sustained coaxing or flattery.
data.Catalyst: A substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction without itself undergoing any permanent chemical change.
data.Cessation: The fact or process of ending or being brought to an end.
data.Chagrin: Distress or embarrassment at having failed or been humiliated.
data.Circumspect: Wary and unwilling to take risks.
data.Cohort: A group of people with a shared characteristic.
data.Commensurate: Corresponding in size or degree; in proportion.
data.Concur: Be of the same opinion; agree.
data.Conjecture: An opinion or conclusion formed on the basis of incomplete information.
data.Conscientious: Wishing to do what is right, especially to do one's work or duty well and thoroughly.
data.Conspicuous: Standing out so as to be clearly visible.
data.Contemplate: Look thoughtfully for a long time at.
data.Contrive: Create or bring about (an object or a situation) by deliberate use of skill and artifice.
data.Cursory: Hasty and therefore not thorough or detailed.
data.Depict: Show or represent by a drawing, painting, or other art form.
data.Derogatory: Showing a critical or disrespectful attitude.
data.Destitute: Without the basic necessities of life.
data.Devout: Having or showing deep religious feeling or commitment.
data.Diatribe: A forceful and bitter verbal attack against someone or something.
data.Affluent: Having a great deal of money; wealthy.
data.Alienate: Cause (someone) to feel isolated or estranged.
data.Altruistic: Showing a selfless concern for the well-being of others; unselfish.
data.Ambiguous: Open to more than one interpretation; unclear.
data.Amorphous: Without a clearly defined shape or form.
data.Anachronistic: Belonging to a period other than that being portrayed.
data.Analogous: Comparable in certain respects, typically in a way that makes clearer the nature of the things compared.
data.Anomalous: Deviation from what is standard, normal, or expected.
data.Antipathy: A deep-seated feeling of dislike; aversion.
data.Apathy: Lack of interest, enthusiasm, or concern.
data.Arduous: Involving or requiring strenuous effort; difficult and tiring.
data.Austere: Severe or strict in manner, attitude, or appearance.
data.Bereft: Deprived of or lacking something, especially a nonmaterial asset.
data.Bucolic: Relating to the pleasant aspects of the countryside and country life.
data.Churlish: Rude in a mean-spirited and surly way.
data.Cloying: Disgust or sicken (someone) with an excess of sweetness, richness, or sentiment.
data.Condescending: Having or showing a feeling of patronizing superiority.
data.Conducive: Making a certain situation or outcome likely or possible.
data.Decrepit: Worn out or ruined because of age or neglect.
data.Diaphanous: Light, delicate, and translucent (usually of fabric).
data.Disparate: Essentially different in kind; not allowing comparison.
data.Dogmatic: Inclined to lay down principles as incontrovertibly true.
data.Emaciated: Abnormally thin or weak, especially because of illness or a lack of food.
data.Erratic: Not even or regular in pattern or movement; unpredictable.
data.Euphoric: Characterized by or feeling intense excitement and happiness.
data.Exhort: Strongly encourage or urge (someone) to do something.
data.Fastidious: Very attentive to and concerned about accuracy and detail.
data.Feckless: Lacking initiative or strength of character; irresponsible.
data.Feral: In a wild state, especially after escape from captivity or domestication.
data.Flippant: Not showing a serious or respectful attitude.
data.Forlorn: Pitifully sad and abandoned or lonely.
data.Glib: (Of words or a speaker) fluent but insincere and shallow.
data.Guileless: Devoid of guile; innocent and without deception.
data.Hackneyed: Lacking significance through having been overused; unoriginal and trite.
data.Hegemony: Leadership or dominance, especially by one country or social group over others.
data.Illicit: Forbidden by law, rules, or custom.
data.Imbue: Inspire or permeate with a feeling or quality.
data.Imperious: Arrogant and domineering ; assuming power or authority without justification.
data.Implacable: Unable to be appeased or placated.
data.Impugn: Dispute the truth, validity, or honesty of (a statement or motive); call into question.
data.Incontrovertible: Not able to be denied or disputed.
data.Infallible: Incapable of making mistakes or being wrong.
data.Intermittent: Occurring at irregular intervals; not continuous or steady.
data.Intransigent: Unwilling or refusing to change one's views or to agree about something.
data.Inundate: Overwhelm (someone) with things or people to be dealt with.
data.Judicious: Having, showing, or done with good judgment or sense.
data.Levity: Humor or frivolity, especially the treatment of a serious matter with humor or in a manner lacking due respect.
data.Machiavellian: Cunning, scheming, and unscrupulous, especially in politics or in advancing one's career.
data.Mawkish: Sentimental in a feeble or sickly way.
data.Neophyte: A person who is new to a subject, skill, or belief.
data.Ostentatious: Characterized by vulgar or pretentious display; designed to impress or attract notice.
data.Parochial: Of or relating to a church parish.
data.Pathos: A quality that evokes pity , sadness, or compassion.
data.Pecuniary: Relating to or consisting of money.
data.Pertinent: Relevant or applicable to a particular matter; apposite.
data.Pervasive: Spreading widely throughout an area or a group of people.
data.Philanthropic: Seeking to promote the welfare of others, especially by donating money to good causes; generous and benevolent.
data.Poignant: Evoking a keen sense of sadness or regret.
data.Propensity: An inclination or natural tendency to behave in a particular way.
data.Querulous: Complaining in a petulant or whining manner.
data.Quintessential: Representing the most perfect or typical example of a quality or class.
data.Reclusive: Avoiding the company of other people; solitary.
data.Redundant: Not or no longer needed or useful; superfluous.
data.Reiterate: Say something again or a number of times, typically for emphasis or clarity.
data.Reminiscent: Tending to remind one of something.
data.Renowned: Known or talked about by many people; famous.
data.Reprieve: Cancel or postpone the punishment of (someone, especially someone condemned to death).
data.Resplendent: Attractive and impressive through being richly colorful or sumptuous.
data.Retrospect: A survey or review of a past course of events or period of time.
data.Reverence: Deep respect for someone or something.
data.Rhetoric: The art of effective or persuasive speaking or writing, especially the exploitation of figures of speech and other compositional techniques.
data.Rife: (of something undesirable or harmful) of common occurrence; widespread.
data.Rudimentary: Involving or limited to basic principles.
data.Stealthy: Behaving, done, or made in a cautious and surreptitious manner, so as not to be seen or heard.
data.Superfluous: Unnecessary, especially through being more than enough.
data.Transcendent: Beyond or above the range of normal or merely physical human experience.
data.Unpretentious: Not attempting to impress others with an appearance of greater importance, talent, or culture than is actually possessed.
data.Utilitarian: Designed to be useful or practical rather than attractive.
data.Virtuoso: A person highly skilled in music or another artistic pursuit.
data.Volatile: Liable to change rapidly and unpredictably, especially for the worse.
data.Zealot: A person who is fanatical and uncompromising in pursuit of their religious, political, or other ideals.
data.Aberration: A departure from what is normal, usual, or expected, typically one that is unwelcome.
data.Abjure: Formally reject or disavow a formerly held belief, usually under pressure.
data.Accolade: An award or privilege granted as a special honor or as an acknowledgment of merit.
data.Accost: Approach and address (someone) boldly or aggressively.
data.Admonition: An act or action of admonishing; authoritative counsel or warning.
data.Aesthetic: Concerned with beauty or the appreciation of beauty.
data.Aggrandize: Increase the power, status, or wealth of.
data.Alias: Used to indicate that a named person is also known or more familiar under another specified name.
data.Alleviate: Make (suffering, deficiency, or a problem) less severe.
data.Allure: The quality of being powerfully and mysteriously attractive or fascinating.
data.Ambivalent: Having mixed feelings or contradictory ideas about something or someone.
data.Anachronism: A thing belonging or appropriate to a period other than that in which it exists, especially a thing that is conspicuously old-fashioned.
data.Analgesic: A remedy that relieves or allays pain.
data.Anecdote: A short amusing or interesting story about a real incident or person.
data.Antecedent: A thing or event that existed before or logically precedes another.
data.Antipodal: Situated on opposite sides of the earth; exactly or approximately opposite.
data.Apex: The top or highest part of something, especially one forming a point.
data.Apotheosis: The highest point in the development of something; culmination or climax.
data.Articulate: Having or showing the ability to speak fluently and coherently.
data.Ascendancy: Occupying a position of dominant power or influence.
data.Assail: Make a concerted or violent attack on.
data.Atrophy: Gradually decline in effectiveness or vigor due to underuse or neglect.
data.Augment: Make (something) greater by adding to it; increase.
data.Avarice: Extreme greed for wealth or material gain.
data.Avuncular: Kind and friendly towards a younger or less experienced person.
data.Baneful: Causing or capable of causing harm or destruction, especially in a gradual or subtle way.
data.Barrage: A concentrated artillery bombardment over a wide area.
data.Bastion: An institution, place, or person strongly defending or upholding particular principles, attitudes, or activities.
data.Begrudge: Envy (someone) the possession or enjoyment of (something).
data.Belie: Fail to give a true notion or impression of (something); disguise or contradict.
data.Bequeath: Leave (a personal estate or one's body) to a person or other beneficiary by a will.
data.Bereave: Be deprived of a loved one through a profound absence, especially due to the loved one's death.
data.Beseech: Ask (someone) urgently and fervently to do something; implore; entreat.
data.Blight: A plant disease, especially one caused by fungi such as mildews, rusts, and smuts.
data.Blithe: Showing a casual and cheerful indifference considered to be callous or improper.
data.Bombastic: High-sounding but with little meaning; inflated.
data.Boon: A thing that is helpful or beneficial.
data.Bourgeois: Of or characteristic of the middle class, typically with reference to its perceived materialistic values or conventional attitudes.
data.Bumptious: Self-assertive or proud to an irritating degree.
data.Candor: The quality of being open and honest in expression; frankness.
data.Capitulate: Cease to resist an opponent or an unwelcome demand; surrender.
data.Carnal: Relating to physical, especially sexual, needs and desires, as opposed to spiritual needs.
data.Dissemble: Conceal one's true motives, feelings, or beliefs.
data.Dissolution: The closing down or dismissal of an assembly, partnership, or official body.
data.Xenophobia: Dislike of or prejudice against people from other countries.
data.Xeric: Of, relating to, or adapted to a dry habitat.
